fields.text: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and cook the spaghetti according to the package instructions until al dente, then drain and set aside. While the pasta cooks, heat the olive oil in a large pan over medium heat, add the chopped onion, and cook for 3–4 minutes until softened. Stir in the garlic and cook briefly until fragrant, then add the ground beef and cook, breaking it up with a spoon, until browned. Mix in the tomato paste, crushed tomatoes, oregano, and basil, adding a little beef stock or water if the sauce is too thick, and season with salt and black pepper. Reduce the heat to low and let the sauce simmer for 20–30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until rich and well combined. Serve the Bolognese sauce over the cooked spaghetti and finish with grated Parmesan cheese and fresh herbs if desired.

Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and cook the pasta according to the package instructions until al dente, then drain and set aside. Heat olive oil or butter in a large pan over medium heat, season the chicken with salt and pepper, and cook until golden and fully cooked, then remove from the pan and slice. In the same pan, melt butter and sauté the garlic briefly until fragrant, then add the heavy cream and let it gently simmer. Stir in grated Parmesan cheese and cook until the sauce thickens and becomes smooth. Add the cooked pasta and sliced chicken to the sauce, toss until evenly coated, and cook for 1–2 minutes more before serving hot.

Heat 3 tbsp oil in a pan over medium heat. Add 2 finely chopped onions and cook until golden brown. Stir in 1 tbsp ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant. Add 2 chopped tomatoes and cook until soft and the oil begins to separate. Mix in 1 tsp coriander powder, 1 tsp cumin powder, ½ tsp turmeric, 1 tsp red chili powder (adjust to taste), and salt. Add 1 kg chicken pieces and stir well to coat with the spices. Cook for 5–7 minutes until the chicken turns white. Pour in 1½ cups water, cover, and simmer on low heat for 20–25 minutes (less for boneless chicken), stirring occasionally. Finish with 1 tsp garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander. Serve hot with rice or roti.

Cook 400g of spaghetti in salted boiling water until al dente. While the pasta cooks, cut 150 g of guanciale (or pancetta) into small pieces and cook in a pan over medium heat until crisp. In a bowl, whisk 3 large eggs with 100 g of finely grated Pecorino Romano cheese and a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper. Once the pasta is done, reserve about a cup of pasta water and drain the rest. Quickly toss the hot pasta with the guanciale off the heat, then add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Add reserved pasta water a little at a time if needed to loosen the sauce. Serve immediately, topped with extra cheese and black pepper.

Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and cook for 2–3 minutes until softened, then add the garlic and cook for 30 seconds until fragrant. Add the ground beef and cook, breaking it apart with a spoon, until browned and fully cooked. Drain excess fat if needed. Stir in chili powder, cumin, paprika, salt, and black pepper. Pour in the water, mix well, and let it simmer for 5–7 minutes until the mixture thickens and becomes flavorful. Warm the taco shells or tortillas according to package instructions. Fill each shell with the beef mixture and add your desired toppings. Serve immediately.

If making homemade croutons: preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Toss small bread cubes with a little olive oil, salt, and pepper. Bake for 5–10 minutes until golden and crisp. For the dressing, combine garlic, anchovies (if using), Dijon mustard, Worcestershire sauce, and lemon juice in a small bowl. Whisk in mayonnaise and olive oil until smooth. Season with salt and pepper to taste. In a large bowl, toss the chopped romaine with the dressing until evenly coated. Sprinkle with grated Parmesan and croutons. Serve immediately.

In a large bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. In another bowl, mix milk, egg, melted butter, and vanilla extract until smooth. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir gently until just combined—small lumps are okay; don’t overmix. Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat and lightly grease with butter. Pour about ¼ cup of batter per pancake onto the skillet. Cook until bubbles form on the surface and the edges look set, about 2–3 minutes. Flip and cook for another 1–2 minutes until golden brown. Serve warm with maple syrup, fresh fruit, or your favorite toppings.

In a large bowl, combine warm water, sugar, and yeast and let sit 5 minutes until foamy. Add flour, salt, and olive oil, mix until a dough forms, then knead 5–7 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled in size. Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F) and place a baking sheet or pizza stone inside. Punch down the dough and roll it out on a floured surface to about 12 inches in diameter, then transfer to parchment paper or a floured pizza peel. Spread tomato sauce evenly over the dough, leaving a small border. Sprinkle mozzarella cheese on top, then arrange pepperoni slices evenly. Sprinkle oregano if using and brush edges with olive oil. Slide pizza onto the preheated baking sheet or stone and bake 12–15 minutes until crust is golden and cheese is bubbling. Let cool 2–3 minutes, slice, and serve immediately.

Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F). In a large bowl, toss sliced apples with sugar, flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, and lemon juice until evenly coated. Roll out one pie crust and fit it into a 9-inch pie pan. Pour the apple mixture into the crust and dot with small pieces of butter. Cover with the second pie crust, trim excess edges, and crimp the edges to seal. Cut a few small slits in the top crust to allow steam to escape. In a small bowl, beat the egg with water and brush over the top crust for a golden finish. Bake at 220°C (425°F) for 20 minutes, then reduce oven temperature to 180°C (350°F) and bake for an additional 30 minutes, until crust is golden and filling is bubbling. Let the pie cool for at least 30 minutes before slicing and serving.

Rinse sushi rice under cold water until water runs clear, then drain. Combine rice and water in a pot, bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 12–15 minutes until water is absorbed. Remove from heat and let sit covered for 10 minutes. In a small bowl, mix rice vinegar, sugar, and salt until dissolved, then fold into the cooked rice and let cool to room temperature. Place a bamboo sushi mat on a clean surface and cover with plastic wrap. Lay one nori sheet shiny side down on the mat. With wet hands, spread a thin layer of rice evenly over nori, leaving about 2 cm at the top edge. Arrange cucumber, avocado, and fish in a line along the bottom edge of the rice. Lift the edge of the mat closest to you and roll tightly away from you, pressing gently to shape the roll. Seal the edge with a little water. Using a sharp knife, slice the roll into 6–8 pieces. Repeat with remaining ingredients. Serve immediately with soy sauce, pickled ginger, and wasabi, optionally sprinkled with sesame seeds.

Crack 2 eggs into a bowl, add a pinch of salt and pepper, and whisk until smooth. Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add a small amount of butter or oil. Once melted, pour in the eggs and let them cook undisturbed for about 1–2 minutes until the edges start to set. Add ½ cup fresh spinach and ¼ cup shredded cheese evenly over one half of the omelette. Let it cook another 1–2 minutes until the eggs are mostly set but still slightly soft on top. Using a spatula, carefully fold the omelette in half over the filling. Cook for an additional 30–60 seconds to melt the cheese and ensure the spinach is tender. Slide the omelette onto a plate and serve immediately while warm.

Slice fresh tomatoes and mozzarella cheese into even rounds, about ½ cm thick. On a serving plate, alternate tomato and mozzarella slices, layering them slightly overlapping. Tuck fresh basil leaves between the layers for flavor and color. Drizzle extra virgin olive oil over the top, then add a small splash of balsamic glaze or reduction if desired. Sprinkle with a pinch of salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Serve immediately as a fresh, light appetizer or side dish.
